column5: A while back my buddy Fisherman donated an old family sleigh. It would seem to be at-least 40+ years old. Hand made. The quality of thisÂ  thing is awesome. I hated to take it and do what I was going to do,but he was fine with it. SO,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Skies Crates A detachable push handle Today was it,s first load and go .This is so easy to push. It,s like pushing a shopping cart. No restriction at all. Thanks pal.     As for the fishing, a perch and herring and snapped a huge pike off at the hole. His head was as big as the 6" hole. I would say it was pushing 15lb. It was huge.
Good guy, Fisherman.Â  I've probably known him since that sled was built.Â  ðŸ˜‰  Why push, instead of pull, Brian?  	Doug

It is so much easier Doug. I started by just pushing my old smitty with my spud bar. I could do it with one hand, it was that easy. This is why I went this method. and ya, his boys sat on this as he pulled them around. He told me the story of the sleigh. The braces are copper pipe. I will disassemble after this winter and give it a good she lac .
I am guessing you are just using it on the flat, like not up and down hills and such?
I pushed it up a boat launch today.LOL  I do not do hills anymore.
Glad you're making use of it.
Those sleds,(my bro has the other) were made in 1982. And I've known Doug since about '79.
I was still in Bagotville until 78, then went to Moisie until Aug 79 and then 1 MP PL.
In my memory, you were one of the "old hands" like Dave Yard when I arrived there.Â  Evidently not..........
Nice rig there B! Good on Fisherman for making it happen With the title I thought you were talking about me!!Â  Â LOL  I see there is not much snow down that way.Â  Better for Ice making
Nice Mr B aka Loony Tooner

Nice!Â  Just bought a 3 man Frabil venture in great condition for $50 andÂ  found a free pair of downhill skis to build a smitty sled! Just need 2 cross pieces then ready to go! How much ice you got in Barrie?
I was on 3.6" black this morning.ðŸ¤£ Will post later,as I am cooking right now.
